comment._content: The machine T.O.M. Sopwith is sitting (or really posing, even in those times people were not really flying in costume !) is the Howard Wright Biplane of 1910. Howard T. Wright was no relation to the Wright brothers. He was an English engineer building flying machines from 1907 on. Incomprehensibly Sopwith bought the machine and startled everybody when he made his first test flight on October 22, 1910 without ever having flown ! Machines were in constant modification, so on the LC picture a structure can be seen in front shielding the aviator from the (cold) wind. Originally the aviator was full blown in the wind. Also can be seen a big fuel tank somewhat behind the pilot. At first a smaller tank was dangerously above the aviator. Sure this is the machine that landed in Windsor Castle on February 1, 1911, probably not in this configuration on the picture. Sopwith took this Howard Wright Biplane to the USA in his 1912 trip, but crashed in the water off Manhattan Beach on September 10, 1912. The machine was completely destroyed, but Sopwith lived on to a very old age in the nineties. Sources: Bruce Robertson - Sopwith. The man and his aircraft. Harleyford, 1970 Peter Lewis - British Aircraft 1809 - 1914. Putnam, 1962 Cheers Kees

comment.author: 68439219@N06
comment._content: Thomas Sopwith arrived in the United States ( New York )on May 6,1911. (Steamship: Hamburg-American  - Amerika) The Howard-Wright aircraft in the photo was lost ( Engine failure)  in the Atlantic Ocean off Brighton Beach, Long Island , New York  Sunday  September 10,1911. Lee Hammond ( Aero Club of America Pilot #34) was passenger . Sopwith replaced aircraft with a Burgess-Wright biplane.
